description.narrative: In Puntland pastoralism, fishing and trading, are the three main economic activities. They are highly complementary and interdependent, and constitute the basis of the present economy. However, poverty rate in Somalia is amongst the highest in the world. It affects 60% of the population in urban households and over 95% of the population in rural households. Puntland is host to an estimated 149,000 IDPs, refugees and asylum seekers and insecurity is the major cause of displacement, followed by drought and the lack of livelihood opportunities. Access to land and water continue to be the primary challenges for host communities and IDP, as well as forced relocation for IDP. Limited livelihoods make it difficult for Somalis to cope with environmental or political shocks. For children, Somalia has been characterized as one of the most challenging countries to grow up in. Only 29% of the children in Somalia attend primary school, and only 7% of the secondary school-age population attends secondary school. Poverty is one of the main reasons why children are sent out to work instead of going to school. In addition, about 33% of girls compared to 21% of boys had to work at home instead of attending school. The partner, Galkayo Education Center for Peace and Development (GECPD), will implement the project in Harfo District, Mudug Region, Puntland Stateand will work in; Decent Work: Collection of data and development of Somalia country profiles for decent work in fragile contexts; Advocacy on development of coherent labour laws;  Advocacy for guidelines on abolishment of child labour; Training and advocacy on establishment of cooperatives and unions. Women Economic Empowerment: Mapping of market needs and opportunities for women; Value chain analysis and private sector development for increased employment opportunities, specifically targeting women; Support to income generating activities, in particular targeting women, youth and IDPs; Entrepreneurship support, in particular for women and youth The actors with the most significant impact on the programme and also those that will be most affected by the programme, include right holders (women, men, youth, IDP and other marginalized groups) CSOs, government bodies, private sector, religious and traditional leaders, local businesses/private sector.
This project mainly contributes to results within Economic empowerment of women. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
